prompt.system_instruction: You are an AI Assistant, tasked with providing responses that are well-grounded in the provided documents. Given one or more documents and a user query, generate a response to the query. If no answer can be found in the documents, say, "I do not have specific information".

messages.speaker: user
messages.text: How do I file a complaint with the state?

messages.speaker: agent
messages.text: To file a complaint with the New York State Attorney General, you can visit their official website and select the category that best fits your purpose. For consumer issues, you can choose from categories like goods or services purchase, credit cards, credit reports, and personal finance, social media, personal data and information privacy, vehicle lease or purchase, and lemon law. If you cannot complete the form online or need additional assistance, you can call their OAG Help Line at 1-800-771-7755. Please note that patterns of complaints often help in allocating law enforcement resources, and filing a false complaint is punishable as a Class A Misdemeanor.

contexts.text:
File a complaint | New York State Attorney General
File a Complaint

How can we help you?

I Want To...

Appeal a background check

Apply for a Job/Internship

Do Business with the OAG

File a Complaint

Find Legal Services

Know My Rights

Make a FOIL Request

Register/Submit a Filing

Report a Data Breach

Request a Publication

Serve Papers on OAG

Use the Whistleblower Portal

Home

 File a complaint
 

File a complaint

Choose the category that best fits your purpose:

 Consumer issues
Vehicles, personal data, credit cards, goods or services purchases, and more

 Housing and real estate
Rent, housing discrimination, unlawful evictions, deed theft, and more

 Technology and information privacy
Technology issues, and data & information privacy

 Health care issues
Medicaid provider fraud, nursing homes, hospitals, and more

 Civil rights and discrimination
Employer discrimination, voting issues, law enforcement, and more

 Employment issues
Wages, conditions, harassment in the workplace, opportunity fraud, and more

 Finance, investment, and lending
Investor fraud, brokers, lenders, credit, financial services, and more

 Public corruption or corporate wrongdoing
Public officials, elected representatives, charitable organizations, and more 

 Charities and fundraising
Charitable organizations or 501(c)(3) corporations

 Fair market and competition
Antitrust violations and patent protections

 

Know what you're looking for?Popular complaint forms for:Consumer fraudDiscriminationEmployment and wagesHealth insurance and providersTechnology and privacy

 

We welcome complaints and whistleblower tips. For consumer issues, we offer a voluntary mediation service if we believe our intervention might assist in resolving the dispute. Patterns of complaints involving the same party or a new issue often help us in allocating our law enforcement resources, regardless of whether we can intervene on any individual complaint.
If you have questions regarding your individual legal rights or responsibilities, contact a private attorney.
If you cannot complete the form online or need additional assistance with where to direct your complaint, please call our OAG Help Line at 1-800-771-7755.
Filing a false complaint is punishable as a Class A Misdemeanor.

messages.text: The information I have does not provide an answer for other states except California, where you can file a complaint online. The whistleblower hotline is 1-800-649-7570, and the Department of Managed Health Care Help Center is 1-888-466-2219.

Translate this website:

California
Public Utilities Commission

Site Search

 

Home
Consumer Support
File a Complaint
Whistleblower Complaint

 
Whistleblower Complaint


 As an employee, contractor, or subcontractor of a company regulated by the Commission, you may report suspected unsafe, unlawful, or dishonest activity. 
 

Report Unsafe Conditions
If the situation is an immediate safety threat, please call 911.
If you are a whistleblower, you can report unsafe conditions — confidentially, if you prefer — to us in the following ways:

Call the whistleblower hotline at 1-800-649-7570

File a Whistleblower Complaint Online

All others can report unsafe conditions to us in the following ways:

Call the whistleblower hotline at 1-800-649-7570

E-mail safetyhotline@cpuc.ca.gov

Who is a “Whistleblower”?
A whistleblower who can be assisted by us is an employee, contractor, or subcontractor of a company regulated by us who reports their employer’s suspected unsafe, unlawful, or dishonest activity. Whistleblowers may report their claims internally to their company’s upper management or to the company’s ethics officer or externally to regulators responsible for regulating the company. A whistleblower’s inside knowledge of the suspected unlawful or dishonest activity may help us discover something we would otherwise not know. Whistleblowers can play a valuable role in helping us get needed evidence to support the claim.
What is the role of the Public Utilities Commission?
We regulate privately owned electric, natural gas, phone, water, railroad, rail transit, and passenger transportation companies.
contexts.title: Whistleblower Complaint

contexts.text:
California Department of Managed Health Care > File a Complaint

We cannot talk to another person about your case unless you sign this form:
Authorized Assistant Form (English), Formulario de Asistente Autorizado (Español)

 

What Happens Next

Within 7 Days

The Help Center will review your application and send you an acknowledgement of receipt letter.

 Expedited IMR decisions are typically determined, if the case has qualified for an IMR and the required documentation has been received by the DMHC's Independent Medical Review organization.

Within 30 Days

 Consumer Complaints are usually decided.

Within 45 Days

 Non-expedited IMRs are usually decided.

 
Have additional questions? Take a look at our Frequently Asked Questions.
 
Other helpful links:

ml.tokens.model_text: file complaint with CA

messages.original_text: The process for filing a complaint with other states may vary. For example, if you want to file a complaint with the California Department of Consumer Affairs, you can visit their website and select the appropriate category for your complaint. They provide options such as filing a complaint against a licensee, submitting a citizen's comment/complaint about the DCA, or reporting unsafe conditions through the whistleblower hotline. Similarly, if you have a complaint related to healthcare in California, you can file a complaint with the California Department of Managed Health Care. Their website provides forms and instructions on how to submit a complaint. It's recommended to check the specific state's department or agency website for detailed information on how to file a complaint.

messages.speaker: user
messages.text: what is NY and CA office hours?

messages.speaker: agent
messages.text: The New York State Attorney General's Offices are open from 8:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday. In contrast, the California Department of Consumer Affairs' Consumer Service Representatives are available to answer consumer, licensee, and applicant questions in over 200 different languages by phone from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday, except on the first and third Wednesday of each month, when they open at 8:30 a.m., and on state-observed holidays.

ml.tokens.model_text: Office of the New York State Attorney General office hours

contexts.text:
Contact Us - California Department of Consumer Affairs
Warranties (excluding appliances and vehicles)
www.insurance.ca.gov

Telephone/cell phone provider complaints & prepaid telephone cards
www.cpuc.ca.gov

Travel - Claims against registered participants of the Travel Consumer Restitution Corporation (for California consumers who suffer losses as a result of the bankruptcy, cessation of operations, insolvency, or material failure of a seller of travel to provide the contracted transportation or travel services.)
www.tcrcinfo.org

Insurance companies
www.insurance.ca.gov

App-based money transmitters
www.dfpi.ca.gov

Online merchants
www.oag.ca.gov

Internet service providers
www.cpuc.ca.gov

Auto purchases and driver's license laws and issues
www.dmv.ca.gov

Consumer Assistance
Consumer service representatives can answer consumer, licensee, and applicant questions in over 200 different languages. They can also assist in the filing of complaints, and mail helpful publications. Automated services are available 24 hours a day, seven days a week.
Our toll-free telephone line is staffed Monday through Friday from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., except on the first and third Wednesday of each month, when we open at 8:30 a.m. We are closed on state-observed holidays.
To submit a public comment, complaint, or suggestion via email, please click here.
Or mail a complaint form to:
 Department of Consumer Affairs
 Consumer Information Center
 1625 North Market Blvd., Suite N 112
 Sacramento, CA 95834
Map and Driving Directions to 1625 North Market Blvd.
To submit a Public Records Act (PRA) request pertaining to a specific DCA entity (board/bureau/committee/program), please contact them directly at: https://www.dca.ca.gov/about_us/entities.shtml.
To submit a PRA request pertaining to DCA but not to a specific DCA entity, please click here.

For additional assistance, call the Consumer Information Center at:
Main: (800) 952-5210

Home

 About the Office
 

About the Office

 

As head of the Department of Law, the Attorney General is both the People's Lawyer and the state's chief legal officer. The Attorney General serves as the guardian of the legal rights of the people of New York, its organizations, and its natural resources. As the state's chief legal counsel, the Attorney General advises the executive branch of state government, and defends actions and proceedings on behalf of the state.

 
Meet Letitia James 

The Attorney General serves the public interest of all New Yorkers in matters affecting their daily lives, enforcing laws to protect consumers, tenants, patients, workers, investors, and charitable donors. The office coordinates statewide civil and criminal investigations, promoting economic and social justice, encouraging harm-reducing public health strategies, and preserving the state’s environment. 
While the Attorney General acts independently of the Governor, the Governor or a state agency may request the Attorney General to undertake specific criminal investigations and prosecutions. The Attorney General's authority also includes the activities and investigations of the Organized Crime Task Force and Medicaid Fraud Control Unit.
The office employs over 1,700 staff, including investigators, analysts, scientists, forensic accountants, legal assistants and support staff, and over 700 assistant attorneys general, serving in over two dozen locations across New York state.  

Department of Law Divisions

Administration

Learn more about the Administration Division

Conviction Review Bureau

contexts.text:
About the Office | New York State Attorney General
The Office of the New York State Attorney General's regional offices help carry out the Attorney General’s essential defensive, regulatory, and affirmative justice functions in every part of the state.Each regional office handles many functions, which may include:representing and defending the state, its officers, and other government agencies in federal and state courtshandling claims and defensive litigation conducting social and economic justice investigations, litigation, and enforcement  prohibiting discrimination and protecting the rights of consumers, senior citizens, tenants, immigrants, and others sponsoring community outreach and educationmediating consumer-frauds cases managing regulatory matters involving charities handling Mental Hygiene Law casesfacilitating Extreme Risk Protection Orders (ERPOs)enforcing the Cannabis Law

Learn more about the Attorney General’s 13 regional offices 

Social Justice Division

The Social Justice Division consists of:

Charities Bureau
Civil Rights Bureau
Environmental Protection Bureau 
Hate Crimes Unit

Labor Bureau
Law Enforcement Misconduct Investigative Office 
Real Estate Finance Bureau

messages.original_text: If you work with the New York State Attorney General's office, you will be working with a team of over 1,700 staff members, including investigators, analysts, scientists, forensic accountants, legal assistants, support staff, and over 700 assistant attorneys general. These professionals serve in various divisions such as Administration, Criminal Justice, Economic Justice, Executive, Regional Offices, Social Justice, Solicitor General, and State Counsel. The specific division and individuals you work with would depend on your role and responsibilities within the office.

messages.speaker: user
messages.text: can you please tell me more about Letitia James?

messages.speaker: agent
messages.text:
Letitia James is the 67th Attorney General for the state of New York, and she is the first woman of color to hold statewide office in New York and the first woman to be elected Attorney General. 

Some recent highlights: Attorney General James Secures $740,000 from Online Mental Health Provider for its Burdensome Cancellation Process; she reaches $310,000 Settlement-in-Principle with Syracuse Landlord for Failing to Address Lead-Based Paint Hazards; she secures $15.2 Million Judgment Against Unlicensed Cannabis Store Owner in Upstate New York; and she also wins Landmark Victory in Case Against Donald Trump.

contexts.text:
Meet Letitia James | New York State Attorney General
She protected New Yorkers’ health and the state’s natural resources by going after polluters and companies that flouted environmental protection laws. Attorney General James stood up for vulnerable populations by going all the way to the U.S. Supreme Court to stop a question about citizenship from being added to the census and successfully protecting DACA. 
She has been a national leader in the fight to defend access to reproductive health care, leading dozens of legal actions across the country to protect and expand access to this lifesaving care. Attorney General James also stood up against corruption and took strong action against officials who broke New York laws or workplace protection measure, regardless of their status or political affiliation.  

Before serving as Attorney General, Letitia James was the public advocate for the City of New York. When she was elected in 2013, she became the first woman of color to hold citywide office. During her tenure as public advocate, her office passed more legislation than all previous public advocates combined, including a groundbreaking law that banned questions about salary history from the employment process to address the pervasive gender wage gap. Prior to serving as public advocate, Letitia James represented the 35th Council District in Brooklyn in the New York City Council for 10 years. As a council member, she passed the Safe Housing Act, legislation that forced landlords to improve living conditions for tenants in New York City’s worst buildings. Before her election to the City Council, Letitia James was head of the Brooklyn Regional Office of the New York State Attorney General’s Office. 
Letitia James began her career as a public defender at the Legal Aid Society. A proud Brooklynite, she is a graduate of Lehman College and Howard University School of Law.

 

Looking for more?

Learn more about the Office of the New York State Attorney General, or view our previous Year in Review. 

About the Office of the New York State Attorney General 
2022 Year in Review 

Letitia James

Home

 Meet Letitia James
 

Meet Letitia James

 

Letitia “Tish” James is the 67th Attorney General for the state of New York. With decades of experience and a long record of achievements, she is a powerful, effective attorney and lifelong public servant. When she was elected in 2018, she became the first woman of color to hold statewide office in New York and the first woman to be elected Attorney General. 

 
View the 2022 Year in Review 

In her first term, Attorney General James focused on protecting vulnerable New York residents and ensuring that individuals or companies that broke state laws were held accountable. She secured more than $7.5 billion for New York from those who broke state laws and took advantage of New Yorkers, including more than $2.5 billion from opioid manufacturers and distributors for their roles in the opioid epidemic. Under her leadership, the Office of the New York State Attorney General helped remove more than 4,000 guns from New York communities, took down dozens of dangerous drug and gun trafficking rings throughout the state, and took legal action to stop the proliferation of ghost guns.
Attorney General James took on predatory landlords who harassed tenants and endangered children by violating New York’s lead paint laws. She protected New Yorkers’ health and the state’s natural resources by going after polluters and companies that flouted environmental protection laws. Attorney General James stood up for vulnerable populations by going all the way to the U.S. Supreme Court to stop a question about citizenship from being added to the census and successfully protecting DACA. 
She has been a national leader in the fight to defend access to reproductive health care, leading dozens of legal actions across the country to protect and expand access to this lifesaving care.

messages.speaker: user
messages.text: wow, that sounds great. maybe tell me more about Office of the New York State Attorney General itself

messages.speaker: agent
messages.text: The office employs over 1,700 staff, including investigators, analysts, scientists, forensic accountants, legal assistants and support staff, and over 700 assistant attorneys general, serving in over two dozen locations across New York state. The New York State Attorney General's Office is responsible for carrying out essential defensive, regulatory, and affirmative justice functions throughout the state. This includes representing and defending the state, its officers, and other government agencies in federal and state courts, handling claims and defensive litigation, conducting social and economic justice investigations, litigation, and enforcement, prohibiting discrimination and protecting the rights of various groups such as consumers, senior citizens, tenants, immigrants, and others. They also sponsor community outreach and education, mediate consumer-frauds cases, manage regulatory matters involving charities, handle Mental Hygiene Law cases, facilitate Extreme Risk Protection Orders (ERPOs), and enforce the Cannabis Law. The office has divisions such as Administration, Criminal Justice, Economic Justice, Executive, Regional Offices, Social Justice, Solicitor General, and State Counsel. Each division has various bureaus and units that focus on specific areas of responsibility.

Home

 About the Office
 

About the Office

 

As head of the Department of Law, the Attorney General is both the People's Lawyer and the state's chief legal officer. The Attorney General serves as the guardian of the legal rights of the people of New York, its organizations, and its natural resources. As the state's chief legal counsel, the Attorney General advises the executive branch of state government, and defends actions and proceedings on behalf of the state.

 
Meet Letitia James 

The Attorney General serves the public interest of all New Yorkers in matters affecting their daily lives, enforcing laws to protect consumers, tenants, patients, workers, investors, and charitable donors. The office coordinates statewide civil and criminal investigations, promoting economic and social justice, encouraging harm-reducing public health strategies, and preserving the state’s environment. 
While the Attorney General acts independently of the Governor, the Governor or a state agency may request the Attorney General to undertake specific criminal investigations and prosecutions. The Attorney General's authority also includes the activities and investigations of the Organized Crime Task Force and Medicaid Fraud Control Unit.
The office employs over 1,700 staff, including investigators, analysts, scientists, forensic accountants, legal assistants and support staff, and over 700 assistant attorneys general, serving in over two dozen locations across New York state.

Learn more about the Administration Division

messages.original_text: The Office of the New York State Attorney General regularly holds press conferences to announce significant actions, investigations, or updates related to their work. These events are typically open to the public and the media. You can find information about upcoming press conferences on the Attorney General's website or through local news outlets. Previous press conference topics include consumer protection, environmental protection, healthcare fraud, data breaches, and major criminal cases.

messages.speaker: user
messages.text: how can I protect myself if I am the whistleblower....

messages.speaker: agent
messages.text: If you are a whistleblower, you can protect yourself by using the Whistleblower Portal provided by the New York State Attorney General's Office. The portal allows anonymous submissions and two-way communications with the office through a unique key code that submitters can use to send and retrieve messages. To begin the anonymous submission process, you need to download and install Tor Browser on your computer, which provides an extra layer of security and privacy to protect your anonymity. After installation, launch Tor Browser and type the following URL into the Tor Browser's address bar: `http://wux56igrepfok5cz5eqszt3xr7ng6tqai2ayplbmvp5qxruax5eicjad.onion`. Once you have accessed the whistleblower portal, you can submit your communication via the simple form that asks for the subject of the communication, a description of the communication, and any supporting files available to upload. After submitting the form, you will receive a secret code to track your submission and communicate with the office anonymously.

Use the Whistleblower Portal

Home

 Whistleblower Portal
 

Office of the New York State Attorney General Whistleblower Portal

The Office of the New York State Attorney General (OAG) welcomes and encourages whistleblowers, tips, and complaints. Whistleblowers are essential to fulfilling our mission: protecting the citizens of New York. Whistleblowing insiders are particularly critical in opaque industries, where transparency is limited.
We take special care to protect whistleblowers. While we encourage whistleblowers to identify themselves, we recognize that many whistleblowers have legitimate concerns about their anonymity because they report conduct by their employers, associates, or community members. The whistleblower portal allows anonymous submissions and two-way communications with our office through a unique key code that submitters can use to send and retrieve messages. As most people understand, the transmission of this information will be anonymous, but the content therein is not guaranteed to remain anonymous and confidential.
To begin the anonymous submission process, follow the instructions below:

1. Download and install Tor Browser on your computer.
Office of the New York State Attorney General uses Tor Browser to provide an extra layer of security and privacy to protect the anonymity of whistleblowers.  Individuals must download and install the Tor Browser on their computer first to connect and access the whistleblower portal. 
To learn more about Tor Browser and how it works, visit the official Tor Browser online documentation. 
2. Launch Tor Browser on your computer.
After installation, open Tor Browser and type the following URL into the Tor Browser's address bar:

http://wux56igrepfok5cz5eqszt3xr7ng6tqai2ayplbmvp5qxruax5eicjad.onion
contexts.title: Whistleblower Portal | New York State Attorney General

ml.tokens.model_text: A whistleblower is an insider with sensitive information about misdeeds by their employer

contexts.text:
Whistleblower Portal | New York State Attorney General
To learn more about Tor Browser and how it works, visit the official Tor Browser online documentation. 
2. Launch Tor Browser on your computer.
After installation, open Tor Browser and type the following URL into the Tor Browser's address bar:

http://wux56igrepfok5cz5eqszt3xr7ng6tqai2ayplbmvp5qxruax5eicjad.onion

If you are unable to reach the whistleblower portal in Tor Browser, refer to Tor Browser's guide to first-time use for additional troubleshooting steps.
Please note that the URL address above will only work inside Tor Browser.  Attempts to visit the URL in your default browser (such as Chrome, Firefox, Safari, or Edge) will not connect.
3. Submit your communication via the whistleblower portal.
The whistleblower portal consists of a simple form that asks individuals to provide the following information:

the subject of the communication
a description of the communication
any supporting files available to upload

Once the form has been submitted, the submitter will receive a secret code to track their submission and communication with our office.

Letitia James
New York State Attorney General
